content.source_1: Coal and natural gas are fossil fuels formed from ancient organic matter over millions of years; their stocks are finite and do not naturally replenish on human timescales.
content.source_2: Wind results from uneven solar heating and Earth’s rotation and is continually produced by atmospheric processes; major energy authorities (e.g., U.S. DOE, IPCC) classify wind as a renewable resource.
content.source_3: Uranium used for nuclear fuel is obtained by mining finite ore deposits; natural processes do not replenish economically recoverable uranium on human timescales.
content.source_4: Utility-scale wind turbines are built with large quantities of steel, concrete, copper, and—in many designs—rare-earth magnets (neodymium, dysprosium) that are extracted from finite mineral deposits.
content.source_5: Extended low-wind meteorological events can persist for days over wide regions, during which wind farms may produce little or no electricity.
content.source_6: Technologies that depend on inputs from finite mined materials require ongoing extraction; if those inputs are depleted or uneconomic and no substitutes are available, the technology cannot continue operating.
